{{use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Search for the Super Battery | image = PBS-SearchForTheSuperBattery-DvdCover.jpg | image_size = 150px | image_alt = | caption = DVD cover | genre = [[Documentary film]] | creator = | based_on = | writer = Daniel McCabe | screenplay = | story = | director = Daniel McCabe | starring = [[David Pogue]] | narrated = [[Jay O. Sanders]] | theme_music_composer = [[APM Music|APM]] | country = United States | language = English | producer = Daniel McCabe | editor = Daniel McCabe | cinematography = Stephen McCarthy | runtime = 53 minutes | company = A [[Nova (TV series)|NOVA production]] by [[Miles O'Brien (journalist)|Miles O’Brien Productions, LLC]], for [[WGBH-TV|WGBH Boston]]. | distributor = [[Public Broadcasting Service]] | budget = | network = [[PBS]] | first_aired = {{Film date|TV=y|2017|02|01}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/tech/super-battery.html }} '''''Search for the Super Battery: Discover the Powerful World of Batteries''''' is a 2017 American [[documentary film]] about [[energy storage]] and how it may help provide an [[environmentally friendly]], or green, future.{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Search for the Super Battery |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/tech/super-battery.html |date=February 1, 2017 |work=[[Public Broadcasting Service]] |accessdate=February 2, 2017}}{{cite web |author=Staff |title=Search for the Super Battery |url=http://pbsinternational.org/programs/search-for-the-super-battery/ |date=February 1, 2017 |work=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS-International]] |accessdate=February 3, 2017 }}{{cite news |last1=Langridge |first1=Max |last2=Edwards |first2=Luke |title=Future batteries, coming soon: Charge in seconds, last months and power over the air |url=http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/130380-future-batteries-coming-soon-charge-in-seconds-last-months-and-power-over-the-air |date=February 2, 2017 |work=Pocket-lint.com |accessdate=February 3, 2017 }} The basic mechanism of [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]], including [[Lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion]] types, is described. The benefits and limitations of various batteries are also presented. Details of seeking a much safer,{{cite news |last=Pogue |first=David |authorlink=David Pogue |title=Exclusive: Tufts professor invents a non-exploding battery that holds 2x as much power |url=http://finance.yahoo.com/news/exclusive-tufts-professor-invents-a-non-exploding-battery-that-holds-2x-as-much-power-202145984.html |date=January 30, 2017 |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |accessdate=February 3, 2017 }} more powerful, longer-lasting and less expensive battery, a so-called "super battery", is discussed. The broad importance of energy storage devices, in [[mobile phone]]s and [[Automotive battery|automobiles]], and in the overall [[Electrical grid|electric grid system]] of the [[United States]], is examined in detail. == Participants == The documentary film is [[Narrator|narrated]] by [[Jay O. Sanders]] and includes the following participants (alphabetized by last name): {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Jay O. Sanders]] ([[Narrator]]) * [[David Pogue]] ([[Master of ceremonies|Host]]) * Guenter Conzelmann ([[Argonne National Lab]]) * George Crabtree ([[Joint Center for Energy Storage Research]]) * Alexis Georgeson ([[Tesla Motors]]) * Denise Gray ([[LG Chem|LG Chem Power]]) * [[Theodore Gray|Theo Gray]] ([[Chemist]] and [[author]]) * [[Daniel Kammen]] ([[University of California, Berkeley]]) * Doug Kim ([[Southern California Edison]]) * Joshua Lamb ([[Sandia National Labs]]) * [[Jay Leno]] ([[Baker Motor Vehicle|1909 electric car owner]]) * Greg Less ([[University of Michigan|University of Michigan (Battery Lab)]]) * Y. Shirley Meng ([[UC San Diego]]) * Jeff Sakamoto ([[University of Michigan]]) * Seth Sanders ([[Flywheel storage power system|Amber Kinetics]]) * [[Cortera|Venkat Srinivasan]] ([[Lawrence Berkeley National Lab]]) * Leigh Anna Steele ([[Sandia National Labs]]) * Levi Thompson ([[University of Michigan]]) * Lynn Trahey ([[Argonne National Lab]]) * Steven Visco ([[Lithium–sulfur battery|PolyPlus Battery Company]]) * [[Aquion Energy|Jay Whitacre]] ([[Aquion Energy]]) * Mike Zimmerman ([[Thermogalvanic cell|Ionic Materials]]) {{div col end}} == Summaries in the media == According to David Templeton of the [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]], the program "walks the viewer through the science of how [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]] work, returning to that theme time and again to explain variations in design to create cheaper, safer, longer-lasting batteries and [[Energy storage|energy-storage systems]]."{{cite news |last=Templeton |first=David |title=NOVA's special episode on batteries includes Carnegie Mellon University technology |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/news/science/2017/01/31/NOVA-s-special-episode-on-batteries-includes-Carnegie-Mellon-University-technology/stories/201701310083 |date=January 31, 2017 |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |accessdate=February 3, 2017 }} Notable discoveries, featured in the program, Templeton reports, are a safe battery "made with [[Saline water|saltwater]] [[electrolytes]]", as well as a safe battery "made of [[plastic]]s that can use [[Lithium|lithium metal]] rather than a traditional [[lithium-ion|lithium ion]] to produce longer-lasting, safe power." Vicky Hallet of the [[Washington Post]] writes that [[Lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion batteries]] "gained widespread popularity because of their ability to pack a lot of energy into a lightweight package." However, such batteries - due to the [[Thermal runaway#Batteries|thermal runaway]] properties of the varieties of lithium-content rechargeable cells that use [[lithium cobalt oxide]] in their positive electrodes - can potentially burst into flames. The program shows several possible ways to make batteries safer.{{cite news |last=Hallet |first=Vicky |title=The search for a battery that won’t blow up in your face |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/the-search-for-a-battery-that-wont-blow-up-in-your-face/2017/01/27/3da59032-e249-11e6-a453-19ec4b3d09ba_story.html |date=January 30, 2017 |work=[[Washington Post]] |accessdate=February 3, 2017 }} Hallet reports that the program presents an important notion: "Batteries are evolving to do more, and do it safely. It’s powerful stuff." {{-}} == Gallery == Image:DavidPogueOct10.jpg|[[David Pogue]]
([[Master of ceremonies|Host]]) Image:Theodore Gray.jpg|[[Theo Gray]]
([[Chemist]] and [[author]]) Image:RAEL NASA Solar Tower480x247 (cropped) Daniel Kammen.png|[[Daniel Kammen]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox power station | name = Shidao Bay Nuclear Power Plant{{cite web | title = Shidao Bay nuclear power plant started at the end of 2012 | url = http://english.qingdao.gov.cn/n2043295/n2048687/275322.html | work = Qingdao Municipal Government | date = 14 January 2013 | accessdate = 13 November 2015}} | name_official = 石島灣核電廠 | image = | image_caption = | location_map = China | coordinates = {{coord|36|57|54|N|122|31|12|E|region:CN-37_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = People's Republic of China | location = [[Rongcheng, Shandong|Rongcheng]], [[Weihai]], [[Shandong]] | status = U | construction_began = {{Start date|2012|12|09}} | commissioned = | decommissioned = | cost = US$16 billion (units 1–7) | owner = [[China Huaneng Group]]
Shandong Shidao Bay Nuclear Power Co., Ltd (HSNPC)
[[Tsinghua University]] | operator = | np_reactor_type = HTGR | np_reactor_supplier = | np_fuel_type = | np_fuel_supplier = | np_cogeneration = | np_cooling_source = [[Heiniwan]] | np_cooling_towers = | ps_units_operational = | ps_units_manu_model = [[HTR-PM]]
[[CAP1400]] | ps_units_uc = 1 × 200 MW
2 × 1400 MW | ps_units_planned = 9 × 200 MW | ps_units_cancelled = | ps_units_decommissioned = | thermal_capacity = | ps_electrical_capacity = | ps_electrical_cap_fac = | ps_storage_hours = | ps_annual_generation = | website = | extra = }} '''Shidao Bay Nuclear Power Plant''' ({{zh|s=石岛湾核电厂|t=石島灣核電廠|p=Shídǎo wān hédiàn chǎng}}), commonly known as '''Shidaowan''', is a [[nuclear power plant]] in [[Shandong]] province, China. The site is located near the Xiqianjia village in Ningjin subdistrict, [[Rongcheng, Shandong|Rongcheng]], [[Weihai]], Shandong. The plant is located about {{convert|23|km}} south of Rongcheng City, {{convert|14|km}} northwest of Shidao, and {{convert|68|km}} southeast of Weihai City.{{cite web | url= http://www.fhdigz.com/en/project_detail.php?id=76 | title= Marine Works of Shidao Bay Nuclear Power Plant| date= May 5, 2014 | work= CCCC-FHDI Engineering | publisher= | accessdate= 2014-07-21 }} The plant will have the first [[Generation IV reactor|fourth-generation]] nuclear reactors in the world: the HTR-PM, a [[high-temperature gas-cooled reactor]] (HTGR) concept. The plant will ultimately have ten 210 MWe ([[MWe|megawatts electrical]]) units of this type. Each unit is made of two HTR-PM reactors driving a single 210 MWe steam turbine. The plant will also host the construction of two 1,500 MWe [[CAP1400]] [[pressurized water reactor]]s, a design based on the [[AP1000]]John A. Mathews; Hao Tan; O'Faircheallaigh (13 August 2015). China’s Renewable Energy Revolution. Palgrave Macmillan UK. pp. 55–. {{ISBN|978-1-137-54625-8}}. jointly developed by [[Westinghouse Electric Company|Westinghouse]] and the [[State Nuclear Power Technology Corporation]] (SNPTC). Shidao Bay nuclear power plant is a joint venture by [[China Huaneng Group]], [[Nuclear power in China|China Nuclear Engineering & Construction Group]], and [[Tsinghua University]]. The total investment of 100 billion [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] (US$15.7 billion) and the 20-year construction plan makes it China's largest planned nuclear project. ==HTR-PM== {{main|HTR-PM}} In 2005, China announced its intention to scale up the [[HTR-10]] experimental reactor for commercial power generation. The first two 250-MWt High-Temperature Reactor-Pebble-bed Modules (HTR-PM) will be installed at Shidao Bay, and together drive a [[steam turbine]] generating 200 [[MWe]]. Originally to be started in 2011, the project was postponed after the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|incident]] at [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]] in [[Japan]] in March 2011. In 2009, it was planned to be finished in 2013.{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.nucengdes.2009.02.023 | volume=239 | title=Current status and technical description of Chinese 2×250MWth HTR-PM demonstration plant | journal=Nuclear Engineering and Design | pages=1212–1219}} Construction finally began at the end of 2012,{{cite web|title=China Begins Construction Of First Generation IV HTR-PM Unit|url=http://www.nucnet.org/all-the-news/2013/01/07/china-begins-construction-of-first-generation-iv-htr-pm-unit|date=7 January 2013}} with the pouring of concrete basemat occurring in April 2014.{{cite web|title=First HTR-PM construction progresses|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-First-CAP1400-reactor-under-construction-0404144.html|date=4 April 2014|accessdate=8 April 2014}} The vessel was installed in 2016. It was expected to begin operating around 2017,{{cite web|title=First vessel installed in China's HTR-PM unit|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/nn-first-vessel-installed-in-chinas-htr-pm-unit-2103164.html|date=21 March 2016|accessdate=7 April 2017}} later postponed to 2018. In December 2017, the pressure vessel head was installed.http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-First-HTR-PM-vessel-head-in-place-0401185.html An updated larger power plant, HTR-PM600, is planned with a capacity of 600 MWe using 6 HTR-PM reactor units.{{cite web|title=China plans further high temperature reactor innovation|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-China-plans-further-high-temperature-reactor-innovation-1909171.html|website=www.world-nuclear-news.org|accessdate=8 November 2017}} ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|China|Energy|Nuclear technology}}}} *[[Nuclear power in China]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Nuclear power in the PRC}} [[Category:Nuclear power stations in China]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Shandong]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with reactors under construction]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with proposed reactors]]

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} [[Image:Staged combustion rocket cycle.png|thumb|right|250px|Fuel-rich staged combustion cycle. Here, all of the fuel and a portion of the oxidizer are fed through the preburner, generating fuel-rich gas. After being run through a turbine to power the pumps, the gas is injected into the combustion chamber and burned with the remaining oxidizer.]]
The '''staged combustion cycle''' (sometimes known as '''topping cycle''' or '''preburner cycle''') is a [[Liquid-propellant rocket#Engine cycles|power cycle]] of a [[bipropellant rocket]] [[Rocket engine|engine]]. In the staged combustion cycle, propellant flows through multiple [[Rocket engine#Combustion chamber|combustion chambers]], and is thus [[combustion|combusted]] in stages. The main advantage relative to other rocket engine power cycles is high [[fuel efficiency]], measured through [[specific impulse]], while its main disadvantage is [[reliability engineering|engineering complexity]].
Typically, propellant flows through two kinds of combustion chambers; the first called ''preburner'' and the second called ''main combustion chamber''. In the preburner, a small portion of propellant is combusted, and the over-pressure produced is used to drive the [[turbopump]]s that feed the engine with propellant. In the main combustion chamber, the propellants are combusted completely to produce [[rocket#Physics|thrust]].
The fuel efficiency of the staged combustion cycle is in part a result of all propellant ultimately flowing to the main combustion chamber; contributing to thrust. The staged combustion cycle is sometimes referred to as '''closed cycle''', as opposed to the [[gas-generator cycle|gas generator, or open cycle]] where a portion of propellant never reaches the main combustion chamber. The engineering complexity is partly a result of the preburner exhaust of hot and highly pressurized gas which, particularly when oxidizer-rich, produces extremely harsh conditions for turbines and plumbing.
==History== Staged combustion (''{{lang|ru|Замкнутая схема}}'') was first proposed by [[Aleksei Mihailovich Isaev|Alexey Isaev]] in 1949. The first staged combustion engine was the [[S1.5400]] (11D33) used in the Soviet planetary rocket, designed by Melnikov, a former assistant to Isaev.<ref name=1st_re >George Sutton, "History of Liquid Propellant Rocket Engines", 2006</ref> About the same time (1959), [[Nikolai Dmitriyevich Kuznetsov|Nikolai Kuznetsov]] began work on the closed cycle engine [[NK-9]] for Korolev's orbital ICBM, GR-1. Kuznetsov later evolved that design into the [[NK-15]] and [[NK-33]] engines for the unsuccessful Lunar [[N1 rocket]]. The non-cryogenic [[Dinitrogen tetroxide|N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>]]/[[Unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine|UDMH]] engine [[RD-253]] using staged combustion was developed by [[Valentin Glushko]] circa 1963 for the [[Proton rocket]].
After the abandonment of the [[N1 (rocket)|N-1]], Kuznetsov was ordered to destroy the NK-33 technology, but instead he warehoused dozens of the engines. In the 1990s, [[Aerojet]] was contacted and eventually visited Kuznetsov's plant. Upon meeting initial skepticism about the high specific impulse and other specifications, Kuznetsov shipped an engine to the US for testing. Oxidizer-rich staged combustion had been considered by American engineers, but deemed impossible.<ref>''Cosmodrome'' History Channel, interviews with Aerojet and Kuznetsov engineers about the history of staged combustion</ref> The Russian [[RD-180]] engine also employs a staged-combustion rocket engine cycle. [[Lockheed Martin]] began purchasing the RD-180 in circa 2000 for the [[Atlas III rocket|Atlas III]] and later, the [[Atlas V rocket|V]], rockets. The purchase contract was subsequently taken over by [[United Launch Alliance]] (ULA), the Lockheed-Martin successor company after 2006, and ULA continues to fly the Atlas V with RD-180 engines as of 2018.
The first laboratory staged-combustion test engine in the West was built in Germany in 1963, by [[Ludwig Boelkow]].{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
[[Hydrogen peroxide]]/[[kerosene]] fueled engines such as the British [[Gamma (Rocket engine)|Gamma]] of the 1950s may use a closed-cycle process by catalytically decomposing the peroxide to drive turbines ''before'' combustion with the kerosene in the combustion chamber proper. This gives the efficiency advantages of staged combustion, while avoiding major engineering problems.
The [[Space Shuttle Main Engine]] is another example of a staged combustion engine, and the first to use liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Its counterpart in the Soviet shuttle was the [[RD-0120]], similar in [[specific impulse]], thrust, and chamber pressure specification to the SSME, but with some differences that reduced complexity and cost at the expense of increased engine weight.
==Variants== Several variants of the staged combustion cycle exist. Preburners that burn a small portion of oxidizer with a full flow of fuel are called ''fuel-rich'', while preburners that burn a small portion of fuel with a full flow of oxidizer are called ''oxidizer-rich''. The RD-180 has an oxidizer-rich preburner, while the RS-25 has two fuel-rich preburners. The [[SpaceX]] [[Raptor (rocket engine family)|Raptor]] has both oxidizer-rich and fuel-rich preburners, a design called ''full-flow staged combustion''.
Staged combustion designs can be either ''single-shaft'' or ''twin-shaft''. In the single-shaft design, one set of preburner and turbine drives both propellant turbopumps. Examples include the [[NPO Energomash|Energomash]] [[RD-180]] and the [[Blue Origin]] [[BE-4]]. In the twin-shaft design, the two propellant turbopumps are driven by separate turbines, which are in turn driven by the outflow of either one or separate preburners. Examples of twin-shaft designs include the [[Rocketdyne]] [[RS-25]], the [[JAXA]] [[LE-7]], and the Raptor. Relative to a single-shaft design, the twin-shaft design requires an additional set of preburner and turbine, but allows for individual control of the two turbopumps.
In addition to the propellant turbopumps, staged combustion engines often require smaller boost pumps so to prevent both preburner [[backflow]] and turbopump [[cavitation]]. For example, the RD-180 and RS-25 use boost pumps driven by [[Tap-off cycle|tap-off]] and [[expander cycle]]s, as well as [[Pressure-fed engine|pressurized tanks]], to incrementally increase propellant pressure prior to entering the preburner.
===Full-flow staged combustion cycle=== [[Image:Full flow staged rocket cycle.png|thumb|right|260px|Full-flow staged combustion rocket cycle]] '''Full-flow staged combustion''' (FFSC) is a twin-shaft staged combustion cycle that uses both oxidizer-rich and fuel-rich preburners. The cycle allows full flow of both propellants through the turbines; hence the name.<ref name=sippel2012/> The fuel [[turbopump]] is driven by the fuel-rich preburner, and the oxidizer turbopump is driven by the oxidizer-rich preburner.<ref name=accrosslinkmag-vol05nbr01 /><ref name=sippel2012> {{cite journal |last=Sippel|first=Martin |author2=Yamashiro, Ryoma |author3=Cremaschi, Francesco |title=Staged Combustion Cycle Rocket Engine Design Trade-offs for Future Advanced Passenger Transport |url=http://elib.dlr.de/78208/1/Prop2012-2.pdf |journal=Space Propulsion 2012 |date=2012-05-10 |series=ST28-5 |accessdate=2014-03-19 |publisher=DLR-SART }}</ref>
Benefits of the full-flow staged combustion cycle include turbines that run cooler and at lower pressure, due to increased mass flow, leading to a longer engine life and higher reliability. As an example, up to 25 flights were anticipated for an engine design studied by the [[German Aerospace Center|DLR (German Aerospace Center)]] in the frame of the [[SpaceLiner]] project.<ref name=sippel2012/> Further, the full-flow cycle eliminates the need for an interpropellant turbine seal normally required to separate oxidizer-rich gas from the fuel turbopump or fuel-rich gas from the oxidizer turbopump,<ref name=nsf20140307> {{cite news |last=Belluscio|first=Alejandro G. |title=SpaceX advances drive for Mars rocket via Raptor power |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/03/spacex-advances-drive-mars-rocket-raptor-power/ |accessdate=2014-03-09 |newspaper=NASAspaceflight.com |date=2014-03-07 }}</ref> thus improving reliability.
Since the use of both fuel and oxidizer preburners results in full gasification of each propellant before entering the combustion chamber, FFSC engines belong to a broader class of rocket engines called gas-gas engines.<ref name=nsf20140307/> Full gasification of components leads to faster chemical reactions in the combustion chamber, which improves performance.
Potential disadvantages of the full-flow staged combustion cycle includes increased engineering complexity of two preburners, relative to a single-shaft staged combustion cycle, as well as an increased parts count. [[Image:SpaceX's Raptor oxygen preburner testing at Stennis (2015).jpg|thumb|left|300px|Oxidizer-rich exhaust from a [[SpaceX]] [[Raptor (rocket engine family)|Raptor]] preburner shown during a sub-system test on a test stand at [[Stennis Space Center]]. In the full-flow rocket engine, the preburner exhaust is fed into a turbine and then into the main combustion chamber.]] Only three full-flow staged combustion rocket engines have ever progressed sufficiently to be tested on test stands; the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[NPO Energomash|Energomash]] [[RD-270]] project in the 1960s, [[SpaceX]]'s [[Raptor (rocket engine)|Raptor]] engine first test-fired in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/780275236922994688 |title=Elon Musk on Twitter: "SpaceX propulsion just achieved first firing of the Raptor interplanetary transport engine" |publisher=[[Twitter]] |date=2009-06-02 |accessdate=2016-09-28}}</ref> , and the [[Federal government of the United States|US government]]-funded [[Aerojet Rocketdyne]] [[Integrated powerhead demonstrator|Integrated powerhead]] demonstration project in the mid-2000s.<ref name=nsf20140307/>
==Applications== ===Oxidizer-rich staged combustion=== *[[S1.5400]]—First staged combustion rocket engine used on the Blok L upper stage.<ref name=1st_re /> *[[NK-33]]—Soviet engine developed for the never-flown upgraded version of the [[N1 (rocket)|N-1]] launch vehicle. Later sold to [[Aerojet Rocketdyne]] and refurbished/remarketed as the AJ-26 (used on [[Antares (rocket)|Antares]] block 1 launch vehicles in 2013–2014). In use on the [[Soyuz-2-1v]]. *[[RD-170]], [[RD-170#RD-171|RD-171]], [[RD-180]] and [[RD-191]]—a series of Soviet and [[Russia]]n engines used on the [[Energia]], [[Zenit (rocket family)|Zenit]], [[Atlas V]], [[Angara (rocket family)|Angara]] and previously on the [[Atlas III]] launch vehicles. RD-171 (and its RD-171M successor), -180 and -191 are derivatives of RD-170. *[[YF-100]]—[[Government of China|Chinese]] engine developed in the 2000s; used on the [[Long March 5]], [[Long March 6]], and [[Long March 7]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Rui C. Barbosa |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/06/china-debuts-long-march-7-rocket/ |title=China successfully debuts Long March 7 – Recovers capsule |website=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=2016-06-25 |accessdate=2016-09-28}}</ref> *[[AR-1 (rocket engine)|AR-1]] An Aerojet Rocketdyne project partially funded by the United States Air Force as a potential replacement for the RD-180 Russian engine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rocket.com/ar1-booster-engine |title=AR1 Booster Engine | Aerojet Rocketdyne |website=Rocket.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-28}}</ref> *[[BE-4]]—[[Blue Origin]] [[Liquid methane|LCH4]]/[[liquid oxygen|LOX]] engine—using the oxygen-rich staged combustion (ORSC) cycle—planned to be used on the [[United Launch Alliance|ULA]] [[Vulcan (rocket)|Vulcan]] launch vehicle, which will replace the [[Atlas V]] and [[Delta IV]], first flight test in 2019<ref name=sc20140917> {{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |title= ULA taps Blue Origin for powerful new rocket engine|url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1409/17ulablueorigin |accessdate=2015-04-13 |newspaper=Spaceflight Now|date=2014-09-17 |quote=''Blue Origin's BE-4 engine uses an oxygen-rich staged combustion cycle, employs a single nozzle, and burns liquid oxygen and liquefied natural gas, a fuel that makes the engine cheaper, less complex, and easier to reuse, according to a fact sheet released by Blue Origin.''}}</ref><ref name=ula2014>{{cite journal |author=Blue Origin |title=BE-4 Rocket Engine |url=http://www.ulalaunch.com/uploads/docs/BE-4_Fact_Sheet_Web_Final_2.pdf |journal=ULA website 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-19 }}</ref> and also on Blue Origin's [[New Glenn]] launch vehicle, with first flight test no earlier than 2020.<ref name=ars20160309>{{cite news |last=Berger|first=Eric |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/03/behind-the-curtain-ars-goes-inside-blue-origins-secretive-rocket-factory/ |title=Behind the curtain: Ars goes inside Blue Origin’s secretive rocket factory |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=2016-03-09 |accessdate=2016-03-12 }}</ref> *[[RD-253]]—[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] engine developed in the 1960s and used on the [[Proton (rocket)|Proton]] launch vehicle's first stage. Later variants include the RD-275 and RD-275M. *[[SCE-200]]—[[ISRO|Indian]] [[RP-1]]/[[LOX]] main stage engine in development.<ref name=sce-200>{{cite journal |author=G.Rohit et.al. LPSC,ISRO |title=Design, Development and testing of Injector for subsystem developemt of Semi Cryogenic engine thrust chamber. |url=https://www.ijirset.com/upload/2013/special/energy/16_DESIGN.pdf |journal=IJIRSET |accessdate=2017-06-13 }}</ref> *Hadley—Ursa Major Technologies<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ursamajortechnologies.com/#engines2|title=Home|website=Ursa Major Technologies|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-20}}</ref> [[liquid oxygen|LOX]]/[[Kerosene]] booster engine under development<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BUK8tdql7TK/?taken-by=ursamajortechnologies|title=Instagram post by Ursa Major Technologies • May 16, 2017 at 11:07pm UTC|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2017-05-20}}</ref> near Denver, Colorado.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.berthoud.org/Home/ShowDocument?id=4603|title=Berthoud Business News|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}{{dead link|date=March 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===Fuel-rich staged combustion=== *[[Space Shuttle main engine|RS-25 (SSME)]]—US developed [[LH2]]/[[LOX]] engine in the 1970–1980s, flown on the [[Space Shuttle]] through 2011 (with periodic upgrades), and planned for further use on the [[Space Launch System]] after 2018. *[[RD-0120]]—[[LH2]]/[[LOX]] engine used on the Energia rocket. *[[LE-7]]—[[LH2]]/[[LOX]] engine used on the H-II rocket family. *[[KVD-1]] (RD-56)—Soviet [[LH2]]/[[LOX]] upper stage engine developed for the never-flown upgraded version of the [[N1 (rocket)|N-1]] launch vehicle. Used on the [[GSLV|GSLV Mk1]]. *[[CE-7.5]]—[[ISRO|Indian]] [[LH2]]/[[LOX]] upper stage engine, used on the [[GSLV|GSLV Mk2]]<ref name=fline20140207>{{cite news |url=http://www.frontline.in/cover-story/gslv-mkiii-the-next-milestone/article5596588.ece |title=GSLV MkIII, the next milestone |work=Frontline |date=2014-02-07 }}</ref> *PGA—[[LH2]]/[[LOX]] engine under development by [[Stratolaunch Systems]]<ref>{{Cite web|title=FACT SHEET: STRATOLAUNCH LIQUID ROCKET ENGINE|url=https://cdn.geekwire.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/PGA-Engine-Fact-Sheet.pdf}}</ref>
===Full-flow staged combustion=== *[[RD-270]]—USSR engine under development 1962–1970 for the UR-700 project; never flown.<ref name=nsf20140307/> *[[Integrated Powerhead Demonstrator|Integrated powerhead demonstrator]]—Demonstration project for the front part of a full flow engine, with no combustion chamber or other backend subsystems.<ref name=nsf20140307/> [[Federal government of the United States|US]] project to develop a part of a new rocket engine technology in the early 2000s; no full engine ever built; never flown. *[[Raptor (rocket engine family)|Raptor]]—SpaceX [[Liquid methane|LCH4]]/LOX engine in development.<ref name=nsf20140307/><ref name=fg20121122> {{cite news |last=Todd|first=David |title=SpaceX’s Mars rocket to be methane-fuelled |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/spacexs-mars-rocket-to-be-methane-fuelled-379326/ |accessdate=2012-12-05 |newspaper=Flightglobal |date=2012-11-22 |quote=''Musk said Lox and methane would be SpaceX’s propellants of choice on a mission to Mars, which has long been his stated goal. SpaceX’s initial work will be to build a Lox/methane rocket for a future upper stage, codenamed Raptor. The design of this engine would be a departure from the “open cycle” gas generator system that the current Merlin 1 engine series uses. Instead, the new rocket engine would use a much more efficient “staged combustion” cycle that many Russian rocket engines use.''}}</ref>
===Current/Past applications of Staged-Combustion engines=== {{div col|colwidth=15em}} *[[Angara (rocket family)]] *[[H-II]] *[[H-IIA]] *[[H-IIB]] *[[GSLV]] *[[Long March 5]] *[[N1 (rocket)]] *[[Proton (rocket family)]] *[[Zenit (rocket family)]] {{div col end}}
===Future applications of Staged-Combustion engines=== *[[BFR (rocket)|BFR launch vehicle and BFR spacecraft]]<ref name=nsf20140307/> *[[New Glenn]] *[[Atlas V successor|Vulcan]]<ref name=ula20140413> {{cite web |title=United Launch Alliance Unveils America’s New Rocket – Vulcan |url=http://www.ulalaunch.com/ula-unveils-americas-new-rocket-vulcan.aspx|website=Ulalaunch.com |accessdate=2015-04-13 }}</ref> *[[SpaceLiner]] [[Reusable launch vehicle|RLV]] project <ref name=sippel2012/>
==See also== * [[Expander cycle (rocket)|Expander cycle]] * [[Gas-generator cycle (rocket)|Gas-generator cycle]] * [[Combustion tap-off cycle]] * [[Pressure-fed engine (rocket)|Pressure-fed engine]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=accrosslinkmag-vol05nbr01>{{cite magazine |last=Emdee |first=Jeff |date=2004 |title=Launch Vehicle Propulsion |url=http://aerospace.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/crosslink/V5N1-cover.jpg |magazine=Crosslink |edition=2004 Winter |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=12–19 |publisher=[[The Aerospace Corporation|Aerospace Corp]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308045601/http://aerospace.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/crosslink/V5N1.pdf |archive-date=2016-03-08 |access-date=2016-09-30 }}</ref> }}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120414212704/http://www.aero.org/publications/crosslink/winter2004/03_sidebar3.html Rocket power cycles] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311011237/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/14oct_betterrocket.htm?list804693 Nasa's full flow stages combustion cycle demonstrator] *[http://www.lpre.de/resources/software/RPA_en.htm Design Tool for Liquid Rocket Engine Thermodynamic Analysis]

page.title: Standard Gibbs free energy of formation

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/137.224.252.11|137.224.252.11]] ([[User talk:137.224.252.11|talk]]) to last version by John of Reading
revision.text:
{{one source|date=December 2011}} The '''standard Gibbs free energy of formation''' of a compound is the change of [[Gibbs free energy]] that accompanies the formation of 1 [[mole (unit)|mole]] of a substance in its [[standard state]] from its constituent elements in their standard states (the most stable form of the element at 1 bar of pressure and the specified temperature, usually 298.15 K or 25 °C).
The table below lists the Standard Gibbs function of formation for several elements and chemical compounds and is taken from Lange's Handbook of Chemistry. Note that all values are in kJ/mol. Far more extensive tables can be found in the [[CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics]] and the NIST JANAF tables.<ref>M.W. Chase, NIST - JANAF Thermochemical Tables, 4th Edition, Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data, Monograph 9, 1998</ref> The [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|NIST]] Chemistry WebBook (see link below) is an online resource that contains [[standard enthalpy of formation]] for various compounds along with the standard [[entropy|absolute entropy]] for these compounds from which the Standard Gibbs Free Energy of Formation can be calculated.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Species ! Phase (Matter) ! Chemical Formula ! ΔG<sub>f</sub><sup>o</sup> (kJ/mol) |- | colspan="4"| '''''[[Aluminum]]''''' |- | [[Aluminum]] | Solid | Al | 0 |- | [[Aluminum Chloride]] | Solid | AlCl<sub>3</sub> | -628.9 |- | [[Aluminum Oxide]] | Solid | Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> | -1582.3 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Barium]]''''' |- |[[Barium]] |Solid |Ba |0 |- | [[Barium Chloride]] | Solid | BaCl<sub>2</sub> | -806.7 |- | [[Barium carbonate|Barium Carbonate]] | Solid | BaCO<sub>3</sub> | -1134.4 |- | [[Barium oxide|Barium Oxide]] | Solid | BaO | -520.4 |- | [[Barium sulfate|Barium Sulfate]] | Solid | BaSO<sub>4</sub> | -1362.2 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Beryllium]]''''' |- | [[Beryllium]] | Solid | Be | 0 |- | [[Beryllium hydroxide|Beryllium Hydroxide]] | Solid | Be(OH)<sub>2</sub> | -815.0 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Boron]]''''' |- | [[Boron trichloride|Boron Trichloride]] | Solid | BCl<sub>3</sub> | -388.7 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Bromine]]''''' |- | [[Bromine]] | Liquid | Br<sub>2</sub> | 0 |- | [[Bromine trifluoride|Bromine Trifluoride]] | Gas | BrF<sub>3</sub> | -229.4 |- | [[Hydrobromic acid|Hydrobromic Acid]] | Gas | HBr | -53.4 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Calcium]]''''' |- | [[Calcium]] | Solid | Ca | 0 |- | [[Calcium carbide]] | Solid | CaC<sub>2</sub> | -64.9 |- | [[Calcium Carbonate]] ([[Calcite]]) | Solid | CaCO<sub>3</sub> | -1129.1 |- | [[Calcium Chloride]] | Solid | CaCl<sub>2</sub> | -748.8 |- | [[Calcium Chloride]] | Aqueous | CaCl<sub>2</sub> | -816.05 |- | [[Calcium Hydride]] | Solid | CaH<sub>2</sub> | -142.5 |- | [[Calcium hydroxide]] | Solid | Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> | -897.5 |- | [[Calcium Oxide]] | Solid | CaO | -603.3 |- | [[Calcium Sulfate]] | Solid | CaSO<sub>4</sub> | -1309.1 |- | [[Calcium sulfide|Calcium Sulfide]] | Solid | CaS | -477.4 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Carbon]]''''' |- | [[Carbon]] ([[Graphite]]) | Solid | C | 0 |- | [[Carbon]] ([[Diamond]]) | Solid | C | 2.900 |- | [[Carbon Dioxide]] | Gas | CO<sub>2</sub> | -394.39 |- | [[Carbonic acid]] | Aqueous | H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> | -623.1 |- | [[Bicarbonate]] | Aqueous | HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> | -586.85 |- | [[Carbonate ion]] | Aqueous | CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> | -527.8 |- | [[Carbon disulfide]] | Gas | CS<sub>2</sub> | 67.1 |- | [[Carbon Monoxide]] | Gas | CO | -137.16 |- | [[Glucose]] | Solid | C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub> | -910.56 |- | [[Ethanol]] | Liquid | C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>5</sub>OH | -174.8 |- | [[Carbonyl Chloride]] ([[Phosgene]]) | Gas | COCl<sub>2</sub> | -204.9 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Caesium]]''''' |- | [[Caesium]] | Solid | Cs | 0 |- | [[Caesium chloride]] | Solid | CsCl | -414.4 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Chlorine]]''''' |- | [[Chlorine]] | Gas | Cl<sub>2</sub> | 0 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Chromium]]''''' |- | [[Chromium]] | Solid | Cr | 0 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Copper]]''''' |- | [[Copper]] | Solid | Cu | 0 |- | [[Copper(I) sulfide]] | Solid | Cu<sub>2</sub>S | -86.2 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Fluorine]]''''' |- | [[Fluorine]] | Gas | F<sub>2</sub> | 0 |- | colspan="4" | '''''[[Hydrogen]]''''' |- | [[Hydrogen]] | Gas | H<sub>2</sub> | 0 |- | [[Water]] | Liquid | H<sub>2</sub>O | {{Infobox film | name = The Garden | image = Gardenposter09.jpg | image_size = | caption = Promotional film poster | director = [[Scott Hamilton Kennedy]] | co-producers = Vivianne Nacif and Dominique Derrenger | writer = Scott Hamilton Kennedy | executive producers = Stuart Sender and Julie Bergman Sender | starring = | music = [[Doug DeAngelis]]
[[Gabriel Tenorio]] | cinematography = Scott Hamilton Kennedy | editing = [[Alex Blatt]]
[[Tyson FitzGerald]]
Scott Hamilton Kennedy | studio = [[Black Valley Films]] | distributor = [[Oscilloscope Laboratories]] | released = {{Film date|2008|6|18}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = United States | language = English / Spanish | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Garden''''' is a 2008 American [[documentary film]] directed by Scott Hamilton Kennedy. It tells the story of the now demolished [[South Central Farm]]; a community garden and [[urban farm]] located in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. ''The Garden'' details the plight of the South Central Farmers, a mostly Latinx community of farmers who organized and worked on the farm. After a suspected back room deal, the land upon which the farm operated was sold from the city back to the original owner, Richard Horowitz. He then decided he did not want to allow the farmers to use it anymore. Despite efforts to keep their farm, the South Central Farmers were evicted and their garden was bulldozed. The film was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature]] on 22 January 2009. ''The Garden'' includes appearances by [[Danny Glover]], [[Daryl Hannah]], and [[Antonio Villaraigosa]]. ==Awards== ''The Garden'' was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature|Best Documentary Feature]] in the [[81st Academy Awards]]. The [[International Documentary Association]] nominated it for the [[Pare Lorentz Award]]. It won the Grand Jury Award from the 2008 [[Silverdocs Documentary Festival]]. ==See also== * [[South Central Farm]] ==External links== * [http://www.blackvalleyfilms.com/ Official site] * {{IMDb title|id=1252486|title=The Garden}} * {{Amg movie|454032|title=The Garden}} * {{Mojo title|id=garden09|title=The Garden}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garden, The}} [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about agriculture in the United States]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:1992 riots]] [[Category:Documentary films about Los Angeles]] [[Category:Urban agriculture]] {{environment-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Tropical cyclone seasonal forecasting''' is the process of predicting the number of [[tropical cyclone]]s in one of the world's seven [[tropical cyclone basin]]s during a particular tropical cyclone season. In the north Atlantic Ocean, one of the most widely publicized annual predictions comes from the [[Tropical Meteorology Project]] at [[Colorado State University]]. These reports are written by Philip J. Klotzbach and [[William M. Gray]].
==Colorado State University's Tropical Meteorology Project== Since 1984, Dr [[William M. Gray]] and his associates at the [[Colorado State University]] has issued a seasonal forecast, that has aimed to predict the number of tropical storms and hurricanes that will develop within the Atlantic basin during the upcoming season amongst other factors. The forecasts were initially issued ahead of time for June and August.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xFpUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cI0DAAAAIBAJ&dq=william%20gray&pg=4468%2C354944|title=El Nino finally seems to be fading|newspaper=Boca Raton News|date=December 2, 1983|accessdate=11 April 2013|author=Toner, Mike|pages=Section 1C}}</ref>
After the active 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, Dr Gray decided to allow Philip J. Klotzbach to take the primary responsibility for the project’s seasonal, monthly and landfall probability forecasts effective with the first forecast for the 2006 Atlantic hurricane season.<ref name="colostate">{{cite web|url=http://hurricane.atmos.colostate.edu/Forecasts/2005/nov2005/|title=SUMMARY OF 2005 ATLANTIC TC ACTIVITY AND VERIFICATION OF SEASONAL AND MONTHLY FORECASTS|publisher=hurricane.atmos.colostate.edu|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> <!-- Over the These predictions have been issued at various times in
Since at least 1994, the Tropical Meteorology Project team at [[Colorado State University]] has issued pre-season predictions in December, April and June for the number of named storms ([[tropical storms]] and [[hurricanes]]), hurricanes and intense hurricanes (category 4 or 5) expected to appear in the [[Atlantic Hurricane | North Atlantic Tropical Cyclone Basin]]. These are one of many predictions issued for storms. Boca Raton News -->
==National Meteorological Services== Ahead of each season several national meteorological services issue forecasts of how many tropical cyclones will form during a season and/or how many tropical cyclones will affect a particular country. Examples include the United Kingdom's [[Met Office]] which issues a {{cite web|url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/research/climate/seasonal-to-decadal/long-range/forecasts |title= seasonal forecast}} in May/June of the number of tropical storms for the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season, while the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Service tries to predict how many tropical cyclones will move into its area of responsibility.
===United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration=== In August 1998, the United States [[Climate Prediction Center]] in conjunction with the [[National Hurricane Center]] and the [[Hurricane Research Division]] issued a tropical cyclone outlook, which accurately predicted that there would be an above-normal number of tropical storms and hurricanes in the Atlantic between August and October.<ref name="noaa">{{cite web|url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories/s193.htm|title=NOAA News Online (Story 193)|publisher=noaanews.noaa.gov|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> The NOAA centres subsequently started to issue an outlook that gave a general guide to the expected overall activity within the Atlantic Ocean.
Ahead of the 2003 Pacific hurricane season, the NOAA forecasters decided to start issuing an experimental tropical cyclone outlook for the Eastern Pacific, which was designed not to be updated during the mid-season.<ref>{{cite web|title=NOAA issues first experimental Eastern Pacific Hurricane Outlook|author=Climate Prediction Center|author2=National Hurricane Center|author3=Hurricane Research Division|date=June 12, 2003|url=http://www.publicaffairs.noaa.gov/releases2003/jun03/noaa03069.html|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=10 August 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812104520/http://www.publicaffairs.noaa.gov/releases2003/jun03/noaa03069.html|archivedate=12 August 2014|df=}}</ref> As a result of both the 2003 and 2004 outlooks being successful, the predictions became an operational product during 2005.<ref name="noaa2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/pa/fstories/2005/0505/fs16may2005a.php|title=NOAA RELEASES EAST PACIFIC HURRICANE SEASON OUTLOOK Below Normal Seasonal Activity Expected in 2005 – Public Affairs – NOAA – NWS|publisher=nws.noaa.gov|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
NOAA is also one of the contributors to New Zealand's [[National Institute of Water & Atmospheric Research]] Tropical Cyclone Outlook, through its [[National Weather Service]] forecast offices in the region and the [[Climate Prediction Center]].<ref name="niwa">{{cite web|url=https://www.niwa.co.nz/sites/default/files/icu151_amj_2013.pdf|date=4 April 2013|title=The Island Climate Update|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
===Australia and the Pacific Islands=== New Zealand's [[National Institute of Water & Atmospheric Research]] (NIWA) and collaborating agencies including the [[Meteorological Service of New Zealand]] and Pacific Island National Meteorological Services issue the "Island Climate Update Tropical Cyclone Outlook" for the Pacific. This forecast attempts to predict how many tropical cyclones and severe tropical cyclones will develop within the Southern Pacific between 135°E and 120°W as well as how many will affect a particular island nation. The [[Fiji Meteorological Service]] while collaborating with NIWA and partners also publishes its own seasonal forecast but for the South Pacific basin between 160°E and 120°W. Since the start of the 2009–10 season, the Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]]'s National Climate Center has publicly released a forecast for the Australian region which focused on the broadscale aspects of the cyclone season, and forecasted how likely it was that a subregion was to see activity above the average as well as how many tropical cyclones may occur within the basin and each of its subregions.<ref name="Seasonal">{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/ahead/tc.html |title=Seasonal Outlook for Tropical Cyclones |date=19 October 2009 |publisher=Bureau of Meteorology |accessdate=26 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mJ8JEHCC?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/ahead/tc.html |archivedate=26 December 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/outlooks/index.shtml |title=Tropical Cyclone Outlooks |author=Staff Writer |year=2009 |publisher=Bureau of Meteorology |accessdate=6 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tGdptCTv?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/outlooks/index.shtml |archivedate=6 October 2010 |df= }}</ref> However ahead of the 2011–12 season the NCC stopped forecasting publicly how many tropical cyclones may occur in a certain region and just forecasted how likely it was that a subregion was to see activity above the average.<ref name="11-12 BoM">{{cite web |title=2011–2012 Australian Tropical Cyclone Season Outlook |publisher=[[Australian Bureau of Meteorology]] |url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/ahead/tc.2011-12.shtml |accessdate=8 January 2013 |author=National Climate Centre |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DVaFWOgr?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/ahead/tc.2011-12.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2013 |date=15 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
